title: The Transfer Portal: A Blueprint to Winning or a Shortcut to Chaos?
text:
The transfer portal has become one of the most significant elements in all of college athletics. Every player seeks a new opportunity, looking for a fresh start, a larger-role, or simply for a better fit. But how much impact do these high-profile transfers have? Are they game-changers, or do they struggle to live up to the hype?
During the 2022-23 offseason, four transfers were very highly proclaimed, and much more so than the rest. Hunter Dickinson of Michigan, Kel’el Ware of Oregon, Dalton Knecht of Northern Colorado, and Grant Nelson of North Dakota State. Each of these players brought star potential to their new homes. Did their individual performances elevate their new teams? Or were their impacts overstated?


Code
transfers |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    Player = "Player",
    Old_School = "Old School",
    New_School = "New School",
    `22-23 PPG` = "PPG (2022-23)",
    `22-23 RPG` = "RPG (2022-23)",
    `22-23 APG` = "APG (2022-23)"
  ) |> 
  tab_header(
    title = "College Basketball's Most Anticipated Transfers",
    subtitle = "Big name players are on the move to big time programs."
  ) |> 
  tab_caption(
    caption = "Source: sports-reference.com | By: Jack Beelman"
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  )






Source: sports-reference.com | By: Jack Beelman


College Basketball's Most Anticipated Transfers


Big name players are on the move to big time programs.


Player
Old School
New School
PPG (2022-23)
RPG (2022-23)
APG (2022-23)




Hunter Dickinson
Michigan
Kansas
18.5
9.0
1.5


Kel'el Ware
Oregon
Indiana
6.6
4.1
0.9


Dalton Knecht
Northern Colorado
Tennessee
20.2
7.3
1.8


Grant Nelson
North Dakota State
Alabama
17.9
9.3
2.1







The insane world that is the transfer portal reshaped the college basketball landscape, with players like Dalton Knecht finding a new home with a plethora of opportunities to excel. But what do these moves mean for their former and new teams? To better understand the ripple effects that the portal is having on the scene, we need to look at how these transfers contribute to overall team performance and how they impact the stats. But first we need to look at their prior year and compare it to how they did in their new home.


Code
ggplot(combined_data_long, aes(x = Player, y = Improvement, fill = Stat)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge") +
  labs(
    title = "Did Transferring Help or Hurt?",
    subtitle = "Some transfers thrived in a new system, but others not so much.",
    x = "Player",
    y = "Improvement",
    caption = "Source: sports-reference.com | By: Jack Beelman"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
    legend.title = element_blank()
  )









As we can see, some of these transfers thrived in a new system under a new head coach. Others not so much, but we have to take into fact that all these players transferred not just schools, but also the conference in which they play in. All of the conferences have their own degree of difficulty to succeed in. I can guarantee that the SEC is a more competitive and has a way higher level of play than the conference Northern Colorado is in.
Let’s take a look at how these transfers helped their new team in the winning department. You would imagine players of this caliber goes to new schools and rise the level of competition and levels of play all around.


Code
team_data <- data.frame(
  Teams = c("Indiana", "Tennessee", "Kansas", "Alabama"),
  WPCT23 = c(0.657, 0.694, 0.778, 0.838),
  WPCT24 = c(0.576, 0.75, 0.676, 0.676)
)


team_data |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    Teams = "School",
    WPCT23 = "Win % (22-23)",
    WPCT24 = "Win % (23-24)"
  ) |> 
  tab_header(
    title = "Did These Transfers Help Bring More Wins?",
    subtitle = "Some players led their new team to success, while others did not live up to the hype"
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |> 
  tab_spanner(
    label = "Source: sports-reference.com | By: Jack Beelman",
    columns = c("Teams", "WPCT23", "WPCT24")
  )








Did These Transfers Help Bring More Wins?


Some players led their new team to success, while others did not live up to the hype


Source: sports-reference.com | By: Jack Beelman


School
Win % (22-23)
Win % (23-24)




Indiana
0.657
0.576


Tennessee
0.694
0.750


Kansas
0.778
0.676


Alabama
0.838
0.676







As expected, a team like Tennessee saw improvements in their winning percentage thanks to the now NBA player Dalton Knecht. It is quite surprising to see teams like Kansas, Alabama, and Indiana with a decrease in their winning percentage, when they added stars through the transfer portal. Despite adding the likes of Hunter Dickinson, Kel’el Ware, and Grant Nelson, these teams experienced a slight dip in their performance, this may suggest that the transition for some players can be more difficult than anticipated.
The transfer portal is an essential tool in shaping college basketball, offering players the opportunity to seek new environments and challenges. While some players excel in their new roles, contributing to team success and improving their individual performance, others may struggle to adapt to new systems, resulting in a drop in their statistics and overall team performance.
In the end, while the transfer portal can provide opportunities for both players and teams, the true value of a transfer player may only be fully realized when they fit seamlessly into their new environment and contribute to both team performance and individual growth.

title: About
text:
Hello! Ny name is Jack Beelman and I am a senior at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and I am majoring in sports media and communications. Welcome to my blog! I enjoy all sports across the board, I am most passionate about English Premier League Soccer, College Basketball and the NFL. Thank you so much for being here!

library(tidyverse)

title: Does Balanced Scoring Lead to Success in the Big East?
text:
The Big East is widely regarded as one of the most competitive conferences in all of college basketball. With powerhouses like UCONN and Villanova winning the NCAA tournament in 4 of the last 8 years, the conference’s dominance is clear. A common question within the Big East revolves around the impact of scoring balance: do teams with more balanced scoring tend to perform better than those relying on one or two star players?
The Big East had multiple players go both in the first and second rounds of the 2024 NBA Draft, but let us see how those players contributed to their team while at the collegiate level. The graph below shows how many players averaged double digit points and for which team they played.


Code
ggplot() +
  geom_bar(
    data = team_double_digit_count,
    aes(x = Team, y = Players_in_double_digits),
    stat = "identity",
    fill = "lightblue"
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "UCONN Dominates Once Again",
    subtitle = "Dan Hurley's squad is filled with stars",
    x = "School",
    y = "Players Averaging Double Digits",
    caption = "Source: sports-reference.com | By: Jack Beelman"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold", hjust = 0),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = "black"),
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "lightgray", color = "black"),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )









It is no surprise that UCONN, the back-to-back National Champions, stands out with five players averaging double-digit points throughout the 2023-2024 season. Teams like Creighton and Marquette also boasted strong performances, each with four double-digit scorers. In contrast, teams such as Butler and St. John’s faced challenges despite a similar scoring balance.
Now how do these players effect the overall winning percentage of their team? That is what the graph below tell us. We know the relationship between offensive depth and team success is clear. The variables in the data hint at many other contributing factors, like defensive prowess and team chemistry. This helps us understand what drives success beyond just scoring.


Code
ggplot() +
  geom_line(
    data = team_performance_clean,
    aes(x = Players_in_double_digits, y = win_percentage, group = 1),
    color = "blue",
    linewidth = 0.8
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = team_performance_clean,
    aes(x = Players_in_double_digits, y = win_percentage),
    color = "blue",
    size = 4
  ) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data = team_performance_clean,
    aes(x = Players_in_double_digits, y = win_percentage, label = Team),
    box.padding = 0.5
  ) +
  geom_hline(
    yintercept = mean(team_performance_clean$win_percentage),
    color = "red",
    linetype = "dashed"
  ) +
  annotate(
    "text",
    x = 2,
    y = mean(team_performance_clean$win_percentage) + 0.02,
    label = "Avg Win%",
    color = "red",
    fontface = "italic"
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Scoring in double figures does wonders",
    subtitle = "UCONN once again is in territory of their own",
    x = "Number of Players Scoring in Double Digits",
    y = "Win Percentage (%)",
    caption = "Source: sports-reference.com | By: Jack Beelman"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold", hjust = 0),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )









Once again one of these is not like the rest. UCONN is by far the best representation to answer the question we initially asked. Having five players all scoring over 10 points a game definitely helps contribute to the overall team’s success and winning percentage. However, Butler seems to be in a surprising spot considering they had the same amount of double digit scorers as Creighton, Marquette, and St. Johns, but fell below the average win percentage in the Big East.
Another conference that is highly proclaimed and is home to the runner-up of the National Championship was the Big 10 Conference. Purdue stood out from the rest, but with 5 other teams that made the NCAA Tournament, the Big 10 in its own right was one of the strongest conferences in all of college basketball in the 2023-2024 season. The trends highlight how certain conferences consistently produce stronger teams, while others show great variability.
The graph below shows us how in comparison each team’s winning percentage in the Big East compared to the Big 10.


Code
  ggplot() +
    geom_line(
      data = combined_team_stats,
      aes(x = Team, y = win_percentage, color = Conference, group = 1),
      linewidth = 1.5
    ) +
    geom_point(
      data = combined_team_stats,
      aes(x = Team, y = win_percentage, color = Conference),
      size = 4
    ) +
    labs(
      title = "UCONN and Purdue dominated the rest of the field", 
      subtitle = "The Huskies and Boilermakers were meant to meet in the final",
      x = "Team",
      y = "Win Percentage (%)",
      caption = "Source: sports-reference.com | By: Jack Beelman"
    ) +
    theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
    theme(
      plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold", hjust = 0),
      plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14),
      axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),
      plot.title.position = "plot"
    )









The comparison highlights the unique identity of each conference. The Big East thrives on unpredictability and moments of absurdness from the marquee programs. The Big Ten embodies steadiness and depth. The are the conferences in college basketball that are shaped by their competition in and out of conference play.
While a high number of double-digit scorers can correlate with success, it is clear that a variety of factors, including defense, depth, and overall team chemistry are needed for success in the long run in college basketball. The Big East and Big Ten both highlight how competitive conferences can thrive with diverse strategies and player contributions.
These two conferences exemplify two different and distinct paths to success in the sport of college basketball. Both conferences remain pillars of the sport, producing thrilling matchups, rivalries, and elite talent. Whether it is balanced scoring or a more star-driven approach, the road to March requires far more than points on a scoreboard. Every possession counts.
